title: Apple removes Hong Kong app amid Chinese criticism
text:
Getty Images Copyright: Getty Images

The UK's GDP number for August is due at 09:30. Could it signal a recession, which is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative growth? in the second quarter it shrank by 0.2% but bounced back to 0.3% expansion in July.

George Buckley, chief UK and eurozone economist at the Japanese bank Nomura tells BBC Radio's 4 Today Programme that economists were forecasting no growth in August.

“Economists are expecting it to be flat so no change at all but in some senses that’s a good thing because the question would be, do you get some payback from the strength in July and if you don't then in the third quarter we could see positive growth [and] avoid this technical recession.

"I think there's a risk we see something worse in 2020 if there is a hard Brexit".

The figure has been volatile because of building up stockpiles ahead of Brexit dates and then winding them down again, he said.

He added that the UK economy was "seeking the knock-on effects of weakening growth everywhere” in the world. Much of that is manufacturing. It becomes more worrying it it "starts to seep into the service sector".
